objection_handlers.objection: My child is too young for the dentist
objection_handlers.response: American Academy of Pediatric Dentistry recommends first visit by age 1 or within 6 months of first tooth. Early visits are fun 'happy visits' that prevent future problems. We see infants daily and make it enjoyable

objection_handlers.objection: Treatment seems expensive for baby teeth that will fall out
objection_handlers.response: Baby teeth hold space for adult teeth and infections can damage permanent teeth developing underneath. Untreated cavities lead to emergency room visits costing $2,000+ versus $200 filling. We offer payment plans and accept most insurance

objection_handlers.objection: My child won't cooperate or sit still
objection_handlers.response: We specialize in anxious children with techniques proven over 15 years. Our tell-show-do method works for 94% of children. We can complete exams with child on parent's lap. First visit is just counting teeth and getting comfortable

objection_handlers.objection: We brush teeth well so don't need dentist
objection_handlers.response: Great home care is important but professional cleanings remove tartar brushing can't. We detect problems early when they're simple to fix. Prevention visits are covered 100% by most insurance with no out-of-pocket cost

We specialize in rebuilding trust with gentle, child-paced approach. Tour our office first without any treatment. Meet our therapy dog. Watch another child's happy visit. 87% of previously fearful children become comfortable patients within 3 visits

Hi [PARENT_FIRST_NAME],

It's 2am. Your child is crying about tooth pain. You're Googling "is this normal" and getting 47 different answers.

We've been there (as pediatric dentists AND parents).

Here's your quick reference guide:

üö® CALL US RIGHT NOW IF:
‚Ä¢ There's swelling in the face or gums
‚Ä¢ Your child has a fever over 101¬∞F
‚Ä¢ They can't sleep or eat at all
‚Ä¢ There's bleeding that won't stop
‚Ä¢ You see pus or abscess

‚è∞ CALL US IN THE MORNING IF:
‚Ä¢ Sensitivity to hot/cold foods
‚Ä¢ Mild pain that comes and goes
‚Ä¢ Discomfort when chewing
‚Ä¢ You notice a dark spot on a tooth

üí° TONIGHT, YOU CAN:
‚Ä¢ Give age-appropriate pain reliever (follow dosing)
‚Ä¢ Apply cold compress to outside of cheek
‚Ä¢ Have them rinse with warm salt water (if old enough)
‚Ä¢ Keep head elevated while sleeping
‚Ä¢ Avoid very hot or cold foods

Cavities spread 2X faster in baby teeth than adult teeth. What seems small on Monday can become an emergency by Friday.
